title: Contemporary Art and Artists - Multiple Choice Questions
subtitle: NIOS Class 12 Painting - Module 2: Historical Appreciation of Indian Contemporary and Miniature Art

questions.question: At the beginning of which century did Indian painters begin painting themes inspired by ancient Indian culture?
questions.explanation: At the beginning of the 20th century, some Indian painters began painting new themes which were directly inspired by the ancient culture of India.

questions.question: Which state was Raja Ravi Varma from?
questions.explanation: During the contemporary period, the biggest name that emerged was Raja Ravi Varma from the state of Travancore (Kerala).

questions.question: What type of subjects did Raja Ravi Varma primarily paint?
options: Stories from epics like Ramayan and Mahabharat, and portraits
questions.explanation: He painted stories from epics and ancient texts such as Ramayan, Mahabharat, portraits, etc.

questions.question: Which art style influenced Raja Ravi Varma's paintings?
questions.explanation: These paintings were influenced by European art.

questions.question: Who were the two artists at the forefront of the Bengal School?
options: Raja Ravi Varma and Rabindranath Tagore
questions.explanation: At the forefront were Abanindranath Tagore and Nandalal Bose from West Bengal, who developed their style of art and built up the 'Bengal School'.

questions.question: Where was Amrita Shergil born?
questions.explanation: Amrita Shergil was a Hungarian-born Indian artist who received her art training in France.

questions.question: What traditional art form did Jamini Roy base his modern style on?
questions.explanation: Jamini Roy introduced a modern style based on Kalighat Pata.

questions.question: When was the Calcutta Group formed?
questions.explanation: The 'Calcutta Group', the first group of modern artists in India, formed in 1943 in Kolkata.

questions.question: Who among the following was a sculptor in the Calcutta Group?
questions.explanation: Its leading members included the sculptor Pradosh Das Gupta and the painters Paritosh Sen, Gopal Ghose, Nirode Mazumdar and Zainul Abedin.

questions.question: When did the Progressive Artists Group hold their first exhibition?
questions.explanation: The Progressive Artists Group held their first exhibition in 1949.

questions.question: When was Raja Ravi Varma born?
questions.explanation: Raja Ravi Varma was born on April 29, 1848, in the royal palace of Kilimanoor, a small town in the southern state of Kerala.

questions.question: Where was Raja Ravi Varma born?
questions.explanation: Raja Ravi Varma was born in the royal palace of Kilimanoor, a small town in the southern state of Kerala.

questions.question: At what age did Raja Ravi Varma start filling walls with pictures?
questions.explanation: At the age of five, he filled the walls of his house with pictures of animals and drawings from day-to-day life.

questions.question: What training did Raja Ravi Varma receive?
options: First in traditional art of Thanjavoor and then European art techniques
questions.explanation: Raja Ravi Varma owed his success to systematic training, first in the traditional art of Thanjavoor and then European art techniques.

questions.question: What did Raja Ravi Varma create with thickly applied oil paints?
options: Lustrous, impasted jewellery and brocaded textures
questions.explanation: With oil paints applied thickly, Ravi Varma created lustrous, impasted jewellery, brocaded textures, and subtle shades of complexions.

questions.question: When did Raja Ravi Varma die?
questions.explanation: Raja Ravi Varma breathed his last on 2nd October 1906.

questions.question: What is the title of Raja Ravi Varma's painting showing Arjuna and Subhadra?
questions.explanation: The painting is titled 'Arjuna and Subhadra' and was created in 1890 C.E.

questions.question: What medium did Raja Ravi Varma use for 'Arjuna and Subhadra'?
questions.explanation: The medium used for 'Arjuna and Subhadra' is Oil on Canvas.

questions.question: Where is 'Arjuna and Subhadra' painting housed?
options: National Gallery of Modern Art, New Delhi
questions.explanation: The painting is in the collection of Maharaja Fateh Singh Museum, Vadodara, Gujarat.

questions.question: From which epic is the painting 'Arjuna and Subhadra' based?
questions.explanation: This painting is based on an incident from Mahabharata, the great Indian epic in which Arjuna, one of the five Pandavas and Subhadra, are shown.

questions.question: Who is Subhadra according to the painting description?
questions.explanation: Subhadra is the only daughter of Vasudeva and Rohini.

questions.question: How is Arjuna disguised in the painting 'Arjuna and Subhadra'?
questions.explanation: Arjuna is in Sanyasi getup and trying to embrace Subhadra.

questions.question: When was Abanindranath Tagore born?
questions.explanation: Abanindranath Tagore was born on 7th August 1871, at Jorasanko (Kolkata) at the family residence of Tagores.

questions.question: Where was Abanindranath Tagore born?
questions.explanation: Born on 7th August 1871, at Jorasanko (Kolkata) at the family residence of Tagores.

questions.question: Where was Abanindranath Tagore educated?
questions.explanation: He was educated at Sanskrit College, Calcutta and took his painting lessons from British and Italian instructors on a private basis.

questions.question: Who helped free Abanindranath from European influence?
questions.explanation: Havell was instrumental in freeing Abanindranath from European influence and drawing his attention to Mughal and Rajput styles.

questions.question: When were Abanindranath's paintings exhibited in London and Paris?
questions.explanation: Abanindranath's paintings were exhibited in London and Paris in 1913, followed by another international exhibition in Japan in 1919.

questions.question: How many paintings by Abanindranath are in Rabindra Bharati Society's collection?
questions.explanation: The largest number of paintings by Abanindranath, over 500, form a part of Rabindra Bharati Society's collection at Jorasanko, Calcutta.

questions.question: Who was Okakura?
options: A great Japanese artist and art critic
questions.explanation: Abanindranath's inner urge for liberating Indian art was further inspired by Okakura, a great Japanese artist and art critic who came to India with Swami Vivekananda.

questions.question: Under whose guidance did Abanindranath study Japanese art?
questions.explanation: Later, Abanindranath studied Japanese art under the guidance of two other Japanese artists, Yokoyama and Hishida.

questions.question: When did Tagore establish the Indian Society of Oriental Art?
questions.explanation: In 1907, Tagore established the Indian society of Oriental Art and developed a style known as 'Bengal School'.

questions.question: What movement was the Bengal School responsible for pioneering?
questions.explanation: The Bengal School was responsible for pioneering the Bengal Revivalist movement.

questions.question: How is Abanindranath Tagore regarded in Indian art history?
questions.explanation: Abanindranath Tagore, regarded as the father of India's modern art, died in 1951.

questions.question: What is the title of Abanindranath's famous painting showing a dying camel?
questions.explanation: The painting is titled 'Journey's End' and was created in 1913 C.E.

questions.question: What medium did Abanindranath use for 'Journey's End'?
questions.explanation: The medium used is Watercolour, wash technique.

questions.question: What new style of painting did Abanindranath evolve?
questions.explanation: Abanindranath combined the Indian tempera techniques with the Japanese water colour evolving a new style of painting called the wash technique.

questions.question: What does the dying camel in 'Journey's End' symbolize?
options: The end of the Mughal empire
A metaphor for the end of a journey, perhaps life compared to the journey of man
questions.explanation: Abanindranath had painted this dying camel as a metaphor for the end of a journey; perhaps life has been compared to the journey of man.

questions.question: What colors did Abanindranath use in 'Journey's End'?
questions.explanation: The artist has sensitively painted the composition using red, ochre and brown shades.

questions.question: Which styles influenced the treatment in 'Journey's End'?
questions.explanation: Treatment in this work is influenced by Mughal and Rajput miniatures.

questions.question: When was Jamini Roy born?
questions.explanation: Jamini Roy was born in Bellator village in the Bankura district of Bengal in 1887 into a middle-class family of landowners.

questions.question: Where was Jamini Roy born?
questions.explanation: He was born in Bellator village in the Bankura district of Bengal in 1887.

questions.question: At what age was Jamini Roy sent to study at the Government School of Art?
questions.explanation: At sixteen he was sent to study at the Government school of art in Kolkata.

questions.question: What influenced Jamini Roy the most in developing his style?
options: Bankura terracotta toys and Kalighat Pata Chitra
questions.explanation: He was most influenced by the Bankura terracotta toys and Kalighat Pata Chitra with its bold sweeping brush strokes.

questions.question: What technique did Jamini Roy use in his paintings?
questions.explanation: Jamini used the traditional tempera technique.

questions.question: What did Jamini Roy use to prepare his canvas?
questions.explanation: In preparation for the canvas, he used cow dung.

questions.question: What was Jamini Roy's threefold quest?
options: To become famous, rich, and celebrated
To capture simplicity, make art accessible, and give Indian art its own identity
To paint portraits, landscapes, and still life
questions.explanation: His underlying quest was threefold: to capture the essence of simplicity embodied in the life of the older people, to make art accessible to a wider section of people, and to give Indian art its own identity.

questions.question: What color did Jamini Roy use river mud for?
questions.explanation: For the grey colour he used river mud.

questions.question: What did Jamini Roy use for red color?
questions.explanation: For red, he used ritual vermillion used by women.

questions.question: What did Jamini Roy use for blue color?
questions.explanation: For blue colour he used indigo.

questions.question: What did Jamini Roy use for black color?
questions.explanation: When he wanted black, it was the black of lamp soot (Kaajal).
